articles.headline: Southern Baptists Move to Purge Churches With Female Pastors
articles.snippet: Some conservatives in the evangelical denomination fear a liberal drift, and are set to vote on a strict ban against women in church leadership. Two churches are appealing their expulsions.
articles.abstract: Some conservatives in the evangelical denomination fear a liberal drift, and are set to vote on a strict ban against women in church leadership. Two churches are appealing their expulsions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The letter in October came as a shock to Linda Barnes Popham, who had been the pastor of Fern Creek Baptist Church in Louisville, Ky., for 30 years, the first woman to lead her congregation. She had served in ministry even longer, since she started as a pianist at age 16.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham

articles.headline: How to Get More Affordable Home Insurance as Costs Soar
articles.snippet: Weather-driven disasters are causing rates to skyrocket in high-risk regions. But there are things owners can do to save on costs.
articles.abstract: Weather-driven disasters are causing rates to skyrocket in high-risk regions. But there are things owners can do to save on costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the 2018 West Fire swept through Alpine, Calif., a small town in the foothills east of San Diego, firefighters were stationed in front of Emily Ziegler’s house, where she lives with her husband and three children.

articles.headline: At a British Amazon Warehouse, a Union Bid Surges, Then Stalls
articles.snippet: Over 700 workers in Coventry joined a union and are seeking recognition for it to negotiate with the company, known for its resistance to organized labor.
articles.abstract: Over 700 workers in Coventry joined a union and are seeking recognition for it to negotiate with the company, known for its resistance to organized labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, as Britain’s inflation rate reached 10 percent, Amazon gave its workers there a pay raise. At a warehouse in Coventry, in the Midlands of England, the offer was for an extra 50 pence (about 63 cents) an hour, or about 5 percent.

articles.headline: Investors Are Putting Big Money Into Japan Again. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: The Japanese stock market is up nearly 30 percent this year, far ahead of the S&P 500, as firms bet that changes in how companies are run might just finally last.
articles.abstract: The Japanese stock market is up nearly 30 percent this year, far ahead of the S&P 500, as firms bet that changes in how companies are run might just finally last.
articles.lead_paragraph: The prime minister, Shinzo Abe, stood in front of the cameras in 2014 and said he was going to shake up the staid ways companies operated in Japan. It was a tall order. Shellshocked by years of economic malaise that followed the bubble of the 1980s, Japanese executives had clung to the status quo for years. Raises for employees and returns for shareholders were scarce. The consequence was an economy that barely grew.

articles.headline: ‘It Doesn’t Count as a War Crime if You Had Fun’: Inside the Minds of Some Russian Soldiers
articles.snippet: At a bar in a once-occupied Ukrainian village, dehumanizing messages on the walls were a stark reminder that the Kremlin wants to stamp out Ukraine and its culture.
articles.abstract: At a bar in a once-occupied Ukrainian village, dehumanizing messages on the walls were a stark reminder that the Kremlin wants to stamp out Ukraine and its culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sweeping out discarded Russian rations, shattered glass and broken furniture was a daunting task. In the four and a half months that Russian forces had occupied a village in eastern Ukraine, the troops had used the local bar as a small outpost, gutting it in the process.

articles.headline: Europeans Take a Major Step Toward Regulating A.I.
articles.snippet: A draft law in the European Parliament has become the world’s most far-reaching attempt to address the potentially harmful effects of artificial intelligence.
articles.abstract: A draft law in the European Parliament has become the world’s most far-reaching attempt to address the potentially harmful effects of artificial intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union took an important step on Wednesday toward passing what would be one of the first major laws to regulate artificial intelligence, a potential model for policymakers around the world as they grapple with how to put guardrails on the rapidly developing technology.

articles.headline: Google’s Online Advertising Practices Violate Antitrust Laws, E.U. Says
articles.snippet: European Union regulators filed new antitrust charges against Google, which could lead to fines and orders for the company to change its business practices.
articles.abstract: European Union regulators filed new antitrust charges against Google, which could lead to fines and orders for the company to change its business practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google was charged on Wednesday with violating European Union antitrust laws by using its dominance in online advertising to undercut rivals, the latest in a string of cases around the world that strike at the core of the internet giant’s business model.

articles.headline: ‘Do You Even Want Us to Exist?’ A Bank Chief Fights to Survive.
articles.snippet: The banks at the center of the recent crisis, like Western Alliance, are engaged in collective soul-searching.
articles.abstract: The banks at the center of the recent crisis, like Western Alliance, are engaged in collective soul-searching.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every quarter for the past several years, Ken Vecchione printed out a spreadsheet comparing the growth of the bank he runs, Western Alliance, with its three principal competitors: First Republic, Signature Bank and Silicon Valley Bank.

articles.headline: Fed Leaves Rates Steady but Forecasts More Moves
articles.snippet: Central bankers have raised rates at the fastest pace since the 1980s, but now they’re taking time to survey how the changes are working.
articles.abstract: Central bankers have raised rates at the fastest pace since the 1980s, but now they’re taking time to survey how the changes are working.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, skipping an increase after raising rates 10 times in a row since March 2022. Still, policymakers predicted that they might need to raise rates two more times this year as inflation, while moderating, remains stubborn.
